newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: SOCCER-MARADONA WINS RAVE REVIEWS FOR LATEST COMEBACK.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-MARADONA WINS RAVE REVIEWS FOR LATEST COMEBACK.

text.p: Diego Maradona awoke to rave reviews after scoring one of Boca Juniors' goals in a 2-0 friendly win against Newell's Old Boys on his fourth comeback to Argentine soccer on Wednesday.

"Maradona: the Legend Lives On!" screamed the front page of Clarin newspaper. Rival daily La Nacion proclaimed: "He's Back -- With a Goal" and Pagina 12 newspaper celebrated "Maradona's Return with a Goal Like the Old Days."

Pagina's sports pages went right over the top, calling the 36-year-old player "The Sun King" and suggesting he "Wants His Throne Back in France" -- predicting Maradona would make it to the 1998 World Cup.

Maradona was given a rapturous reception by a crowd of 20,000 at the Rosario city club Newell's, where he played when he made his second comeback in 1993. Fans from both sides chanted "Ole, Ole, Diego, Diego!" and waved flags and banners proclaiming him "The Envy of the World."
He rewarded them with a goal five minutes into the game, from a free-kick after he had been fouled by Newell's player Diego Mateo just outside the area.

Making his first professional appearance in nearly a year, Maradona looked fitter than for a long time, thanks to training in the Andes and in Canada with sprinter Ben Johnson, with whom he shares the shame of a drugs ban.
His short frame has shed 24 pounds (11 kg) and his hair is plain black rather than dyed in the blue and yellow Boca colours as it was a year ago.

"I felt great and I'm very happy to be back in the shirt that I love," he said in a news conference after the game, which he punctuated with acts of showmanship such as popping off the pitch to shake hands with Newell's coach Mario Zanabria and delaying a corner while talking with adoring fans.

In the past year the hero of Argentina's 1986 World Cup title has been trying to beat his confessed cocaine habit, been involved in a drugs scandal involving his manager Guillermo Coppola and presented a sensationalist television show.

His stamina has apparently suffered and Maradona went off 13 minutes into the second half to a standing ovation, leaving younger players who had never previously played alongside Argentina's sporting idol beside themselves with joy.
"My dream has come true, to play a game with Maradona," said Newell's midfielder Damian Manso.

His teammates believe he is fit enough for a league comeback at home against Racing on Sunday -- with long-suffering Boca fans clinging to the hope that some Maradona magic can lift Boca out of their mid-table blues.
"I thought he looked quick and with good reactions," said Boca's Diego Latorre. "After a few games he'll get into shape for competition."
Maradona himself agreed that "the best training is on the pitch. If this was only about running, Ben Johnson or Carl Lewis would be great players."
